No problem. There will always be a few folks who are not yet used to
the et=
iquette and protocols of the mailing lists. It happens; been
there and done=
 that myself. I think the biggest issue was with folks
who signup on the ma=
iling list and ask "What is JUnit?" Now, that's a
valid question, but I thi=
nk the thought was to provide a list for that
kind of question, so that it =
didn't disturb the flow of the "How do
I?" questions.

My thought is that i=
f we carefully point these folks at the available
documentation on junit.or=
g and suggest reviewing ESR's Smart Question
essay, that they'll either giv=
e up when they see that some personal
effort is involved or they'll appreci=
ate the help and start becoming
productive members of the JUnit community.
=

I also agree with J.B.'s point, that some of these people are the
experts =
of a couple of years from now. You know, Mike Clark isn't
getting any young=
er, so we need to find and train his replacement as
soon as possible! ;-)

=
Simon

--
www.simonpeter.com

> would've asked =
it without thinking about it.  If I weren't familiar
> with Yahoo! Groups, =
I probably wouldn't have thought to check the
> message archives beforehand=
, either.  I'm glad it happened to work
> out that I didn't end up being on=
e of the people this thread is
> about!  What a welcome it would've been!
>=

> Thanks for providing the list, anyway, 'cause it looks interesting so

far.

> -- LeAnne
